contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the phrase "four legs" is an idiom that means to crawl on the ground and sets these insects apart from other flying things, such as birds, that have only two feet. Alternate translation: "insects that crawl on the ground" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: insects that walk on four legs

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means he "firmly decided." Alternate translation: "I have made up my mind to oppose that person" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: I will set my face against that person

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase "to pass through the fire" means to burn something with fire as a sacrifice. Alternate translation: "You must not burn your children alive" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: You must not give any of your children to put them into the fire

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means he "firmly decided." Alternate translation: "I have made up my mind to oppose that man" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: I also will set my face against that man

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means he "firmly decided." Alternate translation: "I have made up my mind that I will oppose that person" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: I will set my face against that person

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase means the man is responsibile for his sin. Alternate translation: "He is responsible for his sin" or "You must punish him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: he must carry his guilt

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idiom "carry your own guilt" means "you are responsible for your own sin." Alternate translation: "You are responsible for your sin" or "I will punish you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: You must carry your own guilt

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase "flowing with milk and honey" means "that is rich and productive with enough food for everyone." Alternate translation: "a land that is excellent for cattle and farming" or "a productive land" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: a land flowing with milk and honey

contextId.occurrenceNote: By marrying an unholy or ungodly woman, the priest would have children unworthy to be priest. Alternate translation: "that he will not have unworthy children by marrying an ungodly woman" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: he will not defile his children among his people

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Generation after generation" here is an idiom that refers to each generation that lives after another. Alternate translation: "your descendants belonging to all future generations may learn" or "all your descendants may learn forever" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: your descendants, generation after generation, may learn

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that means that one life would replace the other. Alternate translation: "one life to replace the other life" or "to replace the one that he killed" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: life for life

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to broken bones. Alternate translation: "broken bone for broken bone" or "If he breaks someone's bone, one of his bones must be broken" or "If he breaks someone's bone, they will break one of his bones" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: fracture for fracture

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to eyes being seriously injured or gouged out. Alternate translation: "If he destroys someone's eye, one of his bones must be destroyed" or "If he destroys someone's eye, they will destroy his eye" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: eye for eye

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to teeth being knocked out of the mouth. Alternate translation: "If he knocks out someone's tooth, one of his teeth must be knocked out" or "If he knocks out someone's tooth, they will knock out one of his teeth" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: tooth for tooth

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that they would eat enough until their stomach was full. Alternate translation: "you will eat till you are full" or "you will eat plenty" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: you will eat your fill

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase "for nothing" means that they would get nothing from their work. Alternate translation: "You will plant your seeds in vain" or "You will plant your seeds, but you will not get anything from them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: You will plant your seeds for nothing

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means he "firmly decided." Alternate translation: "I have made up my mind to oppose you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: I will set my face against you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "seven times" is not literal. It means Yahweh will increase the severity of his punishment. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: seven times

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "seven times" is not literal. It means Yahweh will increase the severity of his punishment. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: seven times

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "seven more times" is not literal. It means Yahweh will increase the severity of his punishment. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: I will punish you even seven more times as much

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Call to mind" here is an idiom meaning "intentionally remember." Here it represents fulfilling his covenant. Alternate translation: "then I will fulfill the covenant I made with Jacob, Isaac, and Abraham" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: then will I call to mind my covenant with Jacob, my covenant with Isaac, and my covenant with Abraham

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Call to mind" here is an idiom meaning "intentionally remember." Here it represents fulfilling his promise concerning the land. Alternate translation: "I will fulfill my promise about the land" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I will call the land to mind

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Call to mind" here is an idiom meaning "intentionally remember." Here it represents fulfilling his covenant. Alternate translation: "I will fulfill the covenant with their ancestors" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I will call to mind the covenant with their ancestors
